SENT.plain: Lymphoma occurs at increased frequency in patients with the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)

We studied, using serologic and molecular techniques, one such lymphoma for (a) evidence of infection with human T lymphotropic virus, type III (HTLV-III), and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), (b) monoclonal rearrangement of immunoglobulin and T cell receptor genes, and (c) rearrangement of the c-myc oncogene
Immunoglobulin and T cell receptor gene studies demonstrated that the tumor was of monoclonal B cell origin
Similar to cases of Burkitt's lymphoma unrelated to AIDS, there were DNA sequences in the lymphoma that hybridized to EBV-specific probes and demonstrated evidence of c-myc rearrangement
HTLV-III sequences were not detected in the malignant B cells

The pathogenesis of some B cell neoplasms in patients with the syndrome may involve transformation by EBV and deregulation of oncogene expression without direct infection of the malignant B cells by HTLV-III
